description.narrative:
Research: Understanding the Links between Masculinities, Femininities, Conflict and Peace
The connection between socially-constructed gender norms and violent conflict is an area of growing interest. It is increasingly recognised that men, and notionsof masculinity, are associated with processes of conflict, violence, and insecurity. Women, conversely, are seen primarily as victims of conflict, despite often playing active roles in both driving conflict and building peace. Despite this, much less understood is the role of femininities, and the influence of gender norms on peace processes. This research seeks to look beyond linking gender norms to thespecific impacts of conflict on women. It will explore the broader relationships between gender, conflict and peace, generating understanding and evidence on the means by which violence and peace are cultivated at the structural and attitudinal levels. In order to gain this fuller understanding, the research will adopt an integrated approach, analysing masculinities as drivers of violent conflict, exploring the role of femininities in conflict, and how gender norms influence, and potentially weaken or can contribute to, peace processes (including those at local, sub-national, national, regional and international, as well as informal or traditional/customary mechanisms, and whether disparity exists between them). The research will explore specific, conflict-affected contexts, asking questions such as what does it mean to be a man in this community, what does it mean to be a woman, and how does this impact conflict and violence, and peace and security? How does a culture of conflict and violence affect concepts of masculinity and femininity?How does masculinity interact with effective peace processes? What role does femininity play in driving conflict and what factors support it? Beginning with the assumption that norms associated with masculinity and femininity influence people#s involvement in conflict and peace processes, Saferworld seeks to analyse how these norms influence people#s decisions to participate in, and their role in, conflict and peacebuilding. In addition, we aim to investigate how these norms impact the ways in which these systems develop and evolve, and how this understanding can be leveraged for positive change. The research will also contribute to greater conflict sensitivity through shedding light on the latent processes by which gender norms and inequality are generated in each target context,with applicability to donor priorities, as well as the strategies adopted and programmes implemented by other (I)NGOs and practitioners.
